byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery reported from Waco, and Serge F. Kovaleski from New York. Alan Blinder contributed reporting from Atlanta, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Jack Begg contributed research.
byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ, SERGE F. KOVALESKI and DAVID MONTGOMERY

abstract: Arrest of 170 bikers on organized-crime charges after deadly shootout in Waco, Tex, has posed challenge to local court system, which is struggling to manage flood of suspects; Waco officials are defending their handling of charges related to shooting, which stemmed from dispute between biker group the Cossacks and its larger rival the Bandidos.
lead_paragraph: Managing the flood of suspects has proved difficult for officials in Waco, Tex., who have been criticized by defense lawyers for setting bond for all defendants at $1 million each.

headline.main: Mass Roundup of Bikers in Waco Shootout Tests Limits of Court System
headline.print_headline: Mass Roundup of Bikers in Waco Shootout Tests Limits of Court System

snippet: Managing the flood of suspects has proved difficult for officials in Waco, Tex., who have been criticized by defense lawyers for setting bond for all defendants at $1 million each.
